text:
I am trying to push an element into a 2d array,
Why does it not work ?

`ERROR: MethodError: no method matching push!(::Array{Int64,2}, ::Array{Int64,2})`

text:
i think you need to use `hcat` or `vcat` depending what you want.
```julia> a = [1 2; 3 4; 5 6]
3×2 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  2
 3  4
 5  6

julia> vcat(a,[7 8])
4×2 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  2
 3  4
 5  6
 7  8```

text:
Usually it's inefficient to construct the matrix first and then assign its values, but here you go:
`a  = Array{Float64, 2}(undef, 1, 2)`
`a = [a; [2.3 3.3]]`

text:
If you are calling functions that return values, then you can do an array comprehension of the form:
`[ func(val) for val in vals ]`
or broadcasting is the neater option:
`func.(vals)`

text: The array comprehension results in Array{Array{Float64, 1}, 1} form, so it creates array of array and running lets say minimum or maximum function on them doesnt run as expected

elements.text: The array comprehension results in Array{Array{Float64, 1}, 1} form, so it creates array of array and running lets say minimum or maximum function on them doesnt run as expected

text:
Here is an example of executing a function using a 2D array comprehension:
```a = [ func(i,j) for i in 1:5, j in 2:10 ]```
If `func` returns an array, then you will get a 2D array of arrays.

elements.text: Here is an example of executing a function using a 2D array comprehension:
a = [ func(i,j) for i in 1:5, j in 2:10 ]
returns an array, then you will get a 2D array of arrays.
